# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result is a transcript of a press conference held by Donald Trump and Emmanuel Macron on February 24, 2025. The transcript includes several instances of Emmanuel Macron speaking, but does not contain the word "butcher" or any direct quotes about Vladimir Putin.

_________________________



SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "French President Emmanuel Macron called Russian President Vladimir Putin a 'butcher' during his press conference with Donald Trump on Monday, Feb. 24, 2025."

## Actions
```
web_search("Emmanuel Macron Vladimir Putin butcher February 24 2025")
web_search("Emmanuel Macron Donald Trump press conference February 24 2025")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.reuters.com/world/macron-arrives-white-house-ukraine-talks-with-trump-2025-02-24/): 
Content: "President Donald Trump shakes hands with French President Emmanuel Macron at the White House in Washington, D.C., U.S., February 24, 2025. President Donald Trump shakes hands with French President Emmanuel Macron at the White House in Washington, D.C., U.S., February 24, 2025. Macron said it was clear that Russia "is the aggressor" in the conflict, a topic Trump [wavered](/world/us/white-house-expects-ukraine-sign-critical-minerals-deal-soon-2025-02-21/)
 on last week.

"President Putin violated the peace," Macron said at a joint press conference with Trump.

Trump expressed a desire for a ceasefire as soon as possible and said he was trying to arrange one between Ukraine and Russia. demands for $500 billion in mineral wealth](/world/ukraine-us-final-stages-agreeing-minerals-deal-kyiv-says-2025-02-24/)
 from Ukraine to repay Washington for wartime aid, saying the United States had supplied nowhere near that sum so far and offered no specific security guarantees in the agreement.

Trump, asked if it was possible that Ukraine might have to cede some territory to Russia, said, "Well, we're going to see." Macron said any deal should include sovereignty for Ukraine.

British Prime Minister Keir Starmer also is to visit Trump later in the week, amid [alarm in Europe](/world/europe/macron-starmer-meet-trump-europeans-flesh-out-ideas-ukraine-guarantees-2025-02-23/)
 over Trump's hardening stance toward Ukraine and overtures to Moscow on the conflict.

Reporting By Andrea Shalal, Michel Rose and Steve Holland; Editing by Colleen Jenkins, Nick Zieminski, Cynthia Osterman and Alistair Bell

Our Standards: [The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles., opens new tab](https://www.thomsonreuters.com/en/about-us/trust-principles.html)

[Michel Rose](/authors/michel-rose/)

Thomson Reuters

Michel reports on French politics and diplomacy, having covered President Emmanuel Macron at the Elysee since 2017 and the rise of the far right under Marine Le Pen. [President Donald Trump](https://www.reuters.com/world/us/donald-trump/)
 and French President Emmanuel Macron displayed stark differences on Monday in their approach to Ukraine, exposing a divide between the United States and Europe over Trump's bid for a quick ceasefire deal with Russia.

During a day of talks between the two leaders, Trump and Macron showed a friendly rapport based on years of good ties. But Macron made clear he disagreed with Trump on some key issues as they marked three years since Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022.

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background.

The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "French President Emmanuel Macron called Russian President Vladimir Putin a 'butcher' during his press conference with Donald Trump on Monday, Feb. 24, 2025."

## Actions
```
web_search("Emmanuel Macron Vladimir Putin butcher February 24 2025")
web_search("Emmanuel Macron Donald Trump press conference February 24 2025")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://rollcall.com/factbase/trump/transcript/donald-trump-press-conference-emmanuel-macron-france-february-24-2025): 
Content: The search result is a transcript of a press conference held by Donald Trump and Emmanuel Macron on February 24, 2025. The transcript includes several instances of Emmanuel Macron speaking, but does not contain the word "butcher" or any direct quotes about Vladimir Putin.


From [Source](https://www.reuters.com/world/macron-arrives-white-house-ukraine-talks-with-trump-2025-02-24/): 
Content: Reuters published an article on February 24, 2025, about a meeting between Emmanuel Macron and Donald Trump at the White House. Macron stated that Russia "is the aggressor" in the conflict. Trump expressed a desire for a ceasefire. <image:1444> The article was written by Andrea Shalal, Michel Rose and Steve Holland.


From [Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/watch-macron-corrects-trump-after-he-says-european-support-for-ukraine-was-a-loan): 
Content: PBS News reports that on February 24, 2025, Emmanuel Macron and Donald Trump held a joint news conference at the White House. The Associated Press is the author.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
On February 24, 2025, Emmanuel Macron and Donald Trump held a press conference at the White House, as reported by [Roll Call](https://rollcall.com/factbase/trump/transcript/donald-trump-press-conference-emmanuel-macron-france-february-24-2025) and [PBS News](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/watch-macron-corrects-trump-after-he-says-european-support-for-ukraine-was-a-loan). Reuters also published an article about the meeting, stating that Macron said Russia was the aggressor, and Trump expressed a desire for a ceasefire <image:1444>.

The transcript from Roll Call does not contain the word "butcher" or any direct quotes about Vladimir Putin.

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "French President Emmanuel Macron called Russian President Vladimir Putin a 'butcher' during his press conference with Donald Trump on Monday, Feb. 24, 2025."

## Actions
```
web_search("Emmanuel Macron Vladimir Putin butcher February 24 2025")
web_search("Emmanuel Macron Donald Trump press conference February 24 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
France 24 ([Source](https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20220327-macron-warns-against-escalation-after-biden-brands-putin-butcher)) reported that Emmanuel Macron warned against escalating the situation in Ukraine after Joe Biden called Vladimir Putin a "butcher" <image:i>. The Moscow Times ([Source](https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2022/03/27/macron-warns-against-escalation-after-biden-brands-putin-butcher-a77097)) also reported on Macron's warning after Biden's comment.

Yahoo News UK ([Source](https://uk.news.yahoo.com/macron-didn-t-call-putin-113000978.html)) states that Macron did not call Putin a "butcher" during a press conference with Donald Trump on February 24, 2025. Instead, Macron was referring to the killings of Ukrainian civilians in Bucha in 2022. The press conference took place at the White House <image:1433>. The Moscow Times also published articles about Trump <image:1437>, <image:1438>, <image:1439>.


### Evidence from `web_search`
On February 24, 2025, Emmanuel Macron and Donald Trump held a press conference at the White House, as reported by [Roll Call](https://rollcall.com/factbase/trump/transcript/donald-trump-press-conference-emmanuel-macron-france-february-24-2025) and [PBS News](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/watch-macron-corrects-trump-after-he-says-european-support-for-ukraine-was-a-loan). Reuters also published an article about the meeting, stating that Macron said Russia was the aggressor, and Trump expressed a desire for a ceasefire <image:1444>.

The transcript from Roll Call does not contain the word "butcher" or any direct quotes about Vladimir Putin.


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim is false. According to Yahoo News UK ([Source](https://uk.news.yahoo.com/macron-didn-t-call-putin-113000978.html)), Macron did not call Putin a "butcher" during the press conference with Trump on February 24, 2025.

The press conference did take place on the specified date at the White House, as confirmed by Roll Call ([Source](https://rollcall.com/factbase/trump/transcript/donald-trump-press-conference-emmanuel-macron-france-february-24-2025)) and PBS News ([Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/watch-macron-corrects-trump-after-he-says-european-support-for-ukraine-was-a-loan)). However, the transcript from Roll Call does not contain the word "butcher."

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "French President Emmanuel Macron called Russian President Vladimir Putin a 'butcher' during his press conference with Donald Trump on Monday, Feb. 24, 2025."

## Actions
```
web_search("Emmanuel Macron Vladimir Putin butcher February 24 2025")
web_search("Emmanuel Macron Donald Trump press conference February 24 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
France 24 ([Source](https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20220327-macron-warns-against-escalation-after-biden-brands-putin-butcher)) reported that Emmanuel Macron warned against escalating the situation in Ukraine after Joe Biden called Vladimir Putin a "butcher" <image:i>. The Moscow Times ([Source](https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2022/03/27/macron-warns-against-escalation-after-biden-brands-putin-butcher-a77097)) also reported on Macron's warning after Biden's comment.

Yahoo News UK ([Source](https://uk.news.yahoo.com/macron-didn-t-call-putin-113000978.html)) states that Macron did not call Putin a "butcher" during a press conference with Donald Trump on February 24, 2025. Instead, Macron was referring to the killings of Ukrainian civilians in Bucha in 2022. The press conference took place at the White House <image:1433>. The Moscow Times also published articles about Trump <image:1437>, <image:1438>, <image:1439>.


### Evidence from `web_search`
On February 24, 2025, Emmanuel Macron and Donald Trump held a press conference at the White House, as reported by [Roll Call](https://rollcall.com/factbase/trump/transcript/donald-trump-press-conference-emmanuel-macron-france-february-24-2025) and [PBS News](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/watch-macron-corrects-trump-after-he-says-european-support-for-ukraine-was-a-loan). Reuters also published an article about the meeting, stating that Macron said Russia was the aggressor, and Trump expressed a desire for a ceasefire <image:1444>.

The transcript from Roll Call does not contain the word "butcher" or any direct quotes about Vladimir Putin.


## Elaboration
The claim is false. According to Yahoo News UK ([Source](https://uk.news.yahoo.com/macron-didn-t-call-putin-113000978.html)), Macron did not call Putin a "butcher" during the press conference with Trump on February 24, 2025.

The press conference did take place on the specified date at the White House, as confirmed by Roll Call ([Source](https://rollcall.com/factbase/trump/transcript/donald-trump-press-conference-emmanuel-macron-france-february-24-2025)) and PBS News ([Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/watch-macron-corrects-trump-after-he-says-european-support-for-ukraine-was-a-loan)). However, the transcript from Roll Call does not contain the word "butcher."


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence indicates that Emmanuel Macron did not call Vladimir Putin a "butcher" during the press conference with Donald Trump on February 24, 2025. While the press conference did occur on that date, the available transcripts and reports do not support the claim.

`false`
_________________________



SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "French President Emmanuel Macron called Russian President Vladimir Putin a 'butcher' during his press conference with Donald Trump on Monday, Feb. 24, 2025."

## Actions
```
web_search("Emmanuel Macron Vladimir Putin butcher February 24 2025")
web_search("Emmanuel Macron Donald Trump press conference February 24 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
France 24 ([Source](https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20220327-macron-warns-against-escalation-after-biden-brands-putin-butcher)) reported that Emmanuel Macron warned against escalating the situation in Ukraine after Joe Biden called Vladimir Putin a "butcher" <image:i>. The Moscow Times ([Source](https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2022/03/27/macron-warns-against-escalation-after-biden-brands-putin-butcher-a77097)) also reported on Macron's warning after Biden's comment.

Yahoo News UK ([Source](https://uk.news.yahoo.com/macron-didn-t-call-putin-113000978.html)) states that Macron did not call Putin a "butcher" during a press conference with Donald Trump on February 24, 2025. Instead, Macron was referring to the killings of Ukrainian civilians in Bucha in 2022. The press conference took place at the White House <image:1433>. The Moscow Times also published articles about Trump <image:1437>, <image:1438>, <image:1439>.


### Evidence from `web_search`
On February 24, 2025, Emmanuel Macron and Donald Trump held a press conference at the White House, as reported by [Roll Call](https://rollcall.com/factbase/trump/transcript/donald-trump-press-conference-emmanuel-macron-france-february-24-2025) and [PBS News](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/watch-macron-corrects-trump-after-he-says-european-support-for-ukraine-was-a-loan). Reuters also published an article about the meeting, stating that Macron said Russia was the aggressor, and Trump expressed a desire for a ceasefire <image:1444>.

The transcript from Roll Call does not contain the word "butcher" or any direct quotes about Vladimir Putin.


## Elaboration
The claim is false. According to Yahoo News UK ([Source](https://uk.news.yahoo.com/macron-didn-t-call-putin-113000978.html)), Macron did not call Putin a "butcher" during the press conference with Trump on February 24, 2025.

The press conference did take place on the specified date at the White House, as confirmed by Roll Call ([Source](https://rollcall.com/factbase/trump/transcript/donald-trump-press-conference-emmanuel-macron-france-february-24-2025)) and PBS News ([Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/watch-macron-corrects-trump-after-he-says-european-support-for-ukraine-was-a-loan)). However, the transcript from Roll Call does not contain the word "butcher."


## Final Judgement
The evidence indicates that Emmanuel Macron did not call Vladimir Putin a "butcher" during the press conference with Donald Trump on February 24, 2025. While the press conference did occur on that date, the available transcripts and reports do not support the claim.

`false`

## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim is false. While a press conference between Emmanuel Macron and Donald Trump did occur on February 24, 2025, at the White House, as reported by [Roll Call](https://rollcall.com/factbase/trump/transcript/donald-trump-press-conference-emmanuel-macron-france-february-24-2025) and [PBS News](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/watch-macron-corrects-trump-after-he-says-european-support-for-ukraine-was-a-loan), Macron did not call Putin a "butcher" during the conference, according to [Yahoo News UK](https://uk.news.yahoo.com/macron-didn-t-call-putin-113000978.html).

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Record

Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

web_search("China Japan invasion Russia")

# Search Result

Content: "For the 1900 Russian invasion, see [Russian invasion of Manchuria](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Manchuria "Russian invasion of Manchuria")

| --- | --- |
| Date | 9–20 August 1945 |
| Location | [Manchuria](/wiki/Manchuria "Manchuria")<br>, [Inner Mongolia](/wiki/Inner_Mongolia "Inner Mongolia")<br>, and northern [Korea](/wiki/Korea "Korea") |
| Result | Soviet victory |
| Territorial  <br>changes | Collapse of Japanese puppet states<br><br>*   Partition of the Korean Peninsula at the [38th parallel](/wiki/Division_of_Korea "Division of Korea")<br>    .<br>*   Most of Manchuria and Inner Mongolia are returned to [the Nationalist government of China](/wiki/Nationalist_government "Nationalist government")<br>     by a 1945 [bilateral agreement](/wiki/Sino-Soviet_Treaty_of_Friendship_and_Alliance "Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance")<br>    <br>*   Parts of [Manchuria](/wiki/Manchuria "Manchuria")<br>     and [Inner Mongolia](/wiki/Inner_Mongolia "Inner Mongolia")<br>     are secretly handed over to the [Chinese Communist Party](/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party "Chinese Communist Party")<br>     [guerrillas](/wiki/Guerrilla "Guerrilla")<br>     after the Soviet withdrawal in 1946 |

**:

Strength

[![Soviet Union](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union_%281936_%E2%80%93_1955%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union_%281936_%E2%80%93_1955%29.svg.png)](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
 **Soviet Union:**

*   1,577,725 troops[\[3\]](#cite_note-glantz378-3)
    
*   27,086 artillery pieces
*   1,152 rocket launchers
*   5,556 tanks and self-propelled guns
*   3,721 aircraft
*   [![Mongolian People's Republic](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Flag_of_the_Mongolian_People%27s_Republic_%281945%E2%80%931992%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Mongolian_People%27s_Republic_%281945%E2%80%931992%29.svg.png)](/wiki/Mongolian_People%27s_Republic "Mongolian People's Republic")
     **Mongolia:**
*   16,000 troops

* * *

*   **Total:**
*   1,593,725 troops
*   27,086 artillery pieces
*   1,152 rocket launchers
*   5,556 tanks and self-propelled guns
*   3,721 aircraft

[![Empire of Japan](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Japan_%281870%E2%80%931999%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_Japan_%281870%E2%80%931999%29.svg.png)](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan")
 **Japan:**

*   _Manchuria:_
*   665,500 soldiers and sailors[\[4\]](#cite_note-:1-4)
    [\[a\]](#cite_note-6)
    
*   290 tanks[\[6\]](#cite_note-7)
    
*   1,042 aircraft (232 combat)[\[7\]](#cite_note-:2-8)
    [\[b\]](#cite_note-9)
    
*   _Korea:_
*   335,900 soldiers and sailors[\[4\]](#cite_note-:1-4)
      
    ~80 tanks[\[c\]](#cite_note-10)
    
*   962 aircraft (395 combat)[\[7\]](#cite_note-:2-8)
    
*   [![Manchukuo](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Flag_of_Manchukuo.svg/40px-Flag_of_Manchukuo.svg.png)](/wiki/Manchukuo "Manchukuo")
     **Manchukuo:**
*   170,000[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
    –200,000 troops[\[8\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJowett53-11)
    
*   [![Mengjiang](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Flag_of_the_Mengjiang.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Mengjiang.svg.png)](/wiki/Mengjiang "Mengjiang")
     **Mengjiang:**
*   44,000 troops

* * *

*   **Total:**
*   1,215,400–1,245,400 troops and sailor
*   370 tanks
*   2,004 aircraft (627 combat)

Casualties and losses

[![Soviet Union](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union_%281936_%E2%80%93_1955%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union_%281936_%E2%80%93_1955%29.svg.png)](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
 **Soviet Union:**

*   9,780–12,031 killed
*   24,425 wounded[\[9\]](#cite_note-12)
    [\[10\]](#cite_note-Coox,_Alvin_D._1939-13)
    
*   300+ tanks destroyed[\[11\]](#cite_note-14)
    
*   [![Mongolian People's Republic](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Flag_of_the_Mongolian_People%27s_Republic_%281945%E2%80%931992%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Mongolian_People%27s_Republic_%281945%E2%80%931992%29.svg.png)](/wiki/Mongolian_People%27s_Republic "Mongolian People's Republic")
     **Mongolia:**
*   72 killed
*   125 wounded[\[12\]](#cite_note-15)
    

* * *

*   **Total:**
*   9,852–12,103 killed
*   24,550 wounded
*   78 Soviet tanks and SPGs
*   62 Soviet combat aircraft[\[13\]](#cite_note-16)
    

[![Empire of Japan](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Japan_%281870%E2%80%931999%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_Japan_%281870%E2%80%931999%29.svg.png)](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan")
 **Japanese medical records:**

*   21,389 killed[\[14\]](#cite_note-17)
    [\[d\]](#cite_note-claim-18)
    
*   Unknown captured in combat
*   Large amounts of equipment captured[\[e\]](#cite_note-19)
    
*   [![Manchukuo](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Flag_of_Manchukuo.svg/40px-Flag_of_Manchukuo.svg.png)](/wiki/Manchukuo "Manchukuo")
     **Manchukuo:**
*   Most troops deserted beforehand[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
    
*   [![Mengjiang](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Flag_of_the_Mengjiang.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Mengjiang.svg.png)](/wiki/Mengjiang "Mengjiang")
     **Mengjiang:**
*   Most troops deserted beforehand[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
    

* * *

*   **Soviet claim:**
*   83,737 killed
*   20,000 wounded[\[d\]](#cite_note-claim-18)
    
*   594,000–609,000 [POWs](/wiki/Prisoner_of_war "Prisoner of war")
    
*   861–925 aircraft
*   369–600 tanks
*   2,576–3,704 guns and mortars captured
*   2,129–2,300 other vehicles captured[\[f\]](#cite_note-20)
    [\[g\]](#cite_note-21)

 \[[ru](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%94%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82_%D0%B2_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82_%D0%A2%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE "ru:Десант в порт Торо")<br>        \]<br>    *   [Otomari](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_assault_on_Otomari&action=edit&redlink=1 "Soviet assault on Otomari (page does not exist)")<br>        <br>*   [Kuril Islands](/wiki/Invasion_of_the_Kuril_Islands "Invasion of the Kuril Islands")<br>    *   [Shumshu](/wiki/Battle_of_Shumshu "Battle of Shumshu")<br>        <br>*   [Hokkaido (cancelled)](/wiki/Proposed_Soviet_invasion_of_Hokkaido "Proposed Soviet invasion of Hokkaido") |     |

The **Soviet invasion of Manchuria**, formally known as the **Manchurian Strategic Offensive Operation**[\[15\]](#cite_note-22)
 or simply the **Manchurian Operation** (Маньчжурская операция) and sometimes **Operation August Storm**,[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 began on 9 August 1945 with the [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
 invasion of the [Empire of Japan](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan")
's [puppet state](/wiki/Puppet_state "Puppet state")
 of [Manchukuo](/wiki/Manchukuo "Manchukuo")
, which was situated in Japanese-occupied [Manchuria](/wiki/Manchuria "Manchuria")
. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)")
     [1-874622-21-3](/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-874622-21-3 "Special:BookSources/1-874622-21-3")
    .

Nagasaki")<br>    <br>*   [Soviet–Japanese War](/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_War "Soviet–Japanese War")<br>    <br>*   [Surrender](/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan "Surrender of Japan")<br>     ([Potsdam Declaration](/wiki/Potsdam_Declaration "Potsdam Declaration")<br>    , [Hirohito surrender broadcast](/wiki/Hirohito_surrender_broadcast "Hirohito surrender broadcast")<br>    )<br>* Search

Search

Soviet invasion of Manchuria

[](#)
[](#)
[](#)
[](#)
[](#)
[](#)
[](#)

39 languages [Add topic](#) The Soviets continued to occupy northern Korea until 1948 and the [Port Arthur](/wiki/Port_Arthur,_China "Port Arthur, China")
 naval base until 1955.

Soviet forces also captured scientists of the Kwantung Army's [Unit 731](/wiki/Unit_731 "Unit 731")
 biological and chemical warfare division, sentencing them in the 1949 [Khabarovsk war crimes trials](/wiki/Khabarovsk_war_crimes_trials "Khabarovsk war crimes trials")
 while allegedly using their information and experience in the [Soviet biological weapons program](/wiki/Soviet_biological_weapons_program "Soviet biological weapons program")
.

Summary
-------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Summary")\
\]

Main article: [Soviet–Japanese War § Summary](/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_War#Summary "Soviet–Japanese War")

As agreed with the United Kingdom and the United States (Western Allies) at the [Tehran Conference](/wiki/Tehran_Conference "Tehran Conference")
 in November 1943 and the [Yalta Conference](/wiki/Yalta_Conference "Yalta Conference")
 in February 1945, the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
 entered World War II's [Pacific Theatre](/wiki/Pacific_War "Pacific War")
 within three months of the [end of the war in Europe](/wiki/Victory_in_Europe_Day "Victory in Europe Day")
. The Japanese did not have any concrete evidence as to when or where any invasion would occur.[\[17\]](#cite_note-Drea-24)
 They had estimated that an attack was not likely before the spring of 1946, but the _[Stavka](/wiki/Stavka "Stavka")
_ had in fact been planning for a mid-August offensive, successfully [concealing the buildup](/wiki/Russian_military_deception "Russian military deception")
 of a force of 90 divisions. This secondary objective was to be carried out by the [25th Army](/wiki/25th_Army_(Soviet_Union) "25th Army (Soviet Union)")
.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 Meanwhile, the [35th Army](/wiki/35th_Army_(Russia) "35th Army (Russia)")
 was tasked with capturing the cities of [Boli](/wiki/Boli_County "Boli County")
 (or Poli), [Linkou](/w/index.php?title=Linkou,_Heilongjiang&action=edit&redlink=1 "Linkou, Heilongjiang (page does not exist)")
 and [Mishan](/wiki/Mishan "Mishan")
.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)

#### 2nd Far Eastern Front

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: 2nd Far Eastern Front")\
\]

The 2nd Far Eastern Front, under General [Maksim Purkayev](/wiki/Maksim_Purkayev "Maksim Purkayev")
, included:[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)

*   [2nd Red Banner Army](/wiki/Soviet_Second_Army "Soviet Second Army")
    
*   [15th Army](/wiki/15th_Army_(Soviet_Union) "15th Army (Soviet Union)")
    
*   [16th Army](/wiki/16th_Army_(Soviet_Union) "16th Army (Soviet Union)")
     (whose 56th Rifle Corps was its only formation to see combat, on [South Sakhalin](/wiki/South_Sakhalin "South Sakhalin")
    )
*   [5th Separate Rifle Corps](/wiki/5th_Separate_Rifle_Corps "5th Separate Rifle Corps")
    
*   [Chuguevsk Operational Group](/w/index.php?title=Chuguevsk_Operational_Group&action=edit&redlink=1 "Chuguevsk Operational Group (page does not exist)")
    
*   [Amur Military Flotilla](/wiki/Amur_Military_Flotilla "Amur Military Flotilla")
    
*   [10th Air Army](/wiki/10th_Air_Army "10th Air Army")
    

The 2nd Far Eastern Front was deployed in a supporting attack role.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 Its objectives were the cities of Harbin and Qiqihar,[\[2\]](#cite_note-Battlefield_Series-2)
 and to prevent an orderly withdrawal to the south by the Japanese forces.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 The front also included the [88th Separate Rifle Brigade](/wiki/88th_Separate_Rifle_Brigade "88th Separate Rifle Brigade")
, composed of Chinese and Korean guerrillas of the [Northeast Anti-Japanese United Army](/wiki/Northeast_Anti-Japanese_United_Army "Northeast Anti-Japanese United Army")
 who had retreated into the USSR in the beginning of the 1940s. The Kwantung Army commanders were engaged in a planning exercise at the time of the invasion, and were away from their forces for the first eighteen hours of conflict.

The Russians treated the Japanese with the utmost cruelty after their deadly attack on Japan's Kwantung Army in Manchuria just days before Japan's surrender.[\[38\]](#cite_note-46)
 Japanese forces were overwhelmed by Soviet attacks. Soviet paratroopers destroyed the Kwantung Army from behind its own lines, while Japanese anti-tank shells bounced off the sides of Soviet tanks.[\[39\]](#cite_note-47)
 The Japanese forces in Manchuria retreated in fear.[\[40\]](#cite_note-48)

Japanese troops and able-bodied Japanese men in Manchuria were taken prisoner by the Russians and transported to labor camps in Siberia, where many Japanese men would die.[\[41\]](#cite_note-49)
 From the Russians' perspective, this was seen as revenge for Russia's defeat in the [Russo-Japanese War](/wiki/Russo-Japanese_War "Russo-Japanese War")
 of 1905.[\[42\]](#cite_note-50)
 The stories of how poorly the Soviets treated the Japanese were brought to [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing "Beijing")
 by Japanese evacuees of Manchuria, creating panic among the Japanese population; however, the Russians honored their agreement with Chiang Kai-shek by not entering China proper.[\[43\]](#cite_note-51)

Japanese communication infrastructure was poor, and the Japanese lost communication with forward units very early on. Later, on 8 September 1945, American forces landed at [Incheon](/wiki/Incheon "Incheon")
.

Aftermath
---------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Aftermath")\
\]

See also: [Soviet–Japanese War § Importance and consequences](/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_War#Importance_and_consequences "Soviet–Japanese War")
, and [Khabarovsk War Crime Trials](/wiki/Khabarovsk_War_Crime_Trials "Khabarovsk War Crime Trials")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/%E8%8B%8F%E8%81%94%E7%BA%A2%E5%86%9B%E7%83%88%E5%A3%AB%E5%85%AC%E5%9B%AD_-_panoramio.jpg/250px-%E8%8B%8F%E8%81%94%E7%BA%A2%E5%86%9B%E7%83%88%E5%A3%AB%E5%85%AC%E5%9B%AD_-_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:%E8%8B%8F%E8%81%94%E7%BA%A2%E5%86%9B%E7%83%88%E5%A3%AB%E5%85%AC%E5%9B%AD_-_panoramio.jpg)

Soviet Red Army Martyrs Cemetery built in [Manzhouli](/wiki/Manzhouli "Manzhouli")
 after the war

The invasion of Manchuria was a factor that contributed to the surrender of Japan and the end of World War II.

In September 1945, the [Chinese Communist Party](/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party "Chinese Communist Party")
 (CCP) dispatched soldiers to Soviet-occupied Manchuria.[\[53\]](#cite_note-:0222-61)
: 73  The CCP obtained Japanese arms with Soviet help.[\[53\]](#cite_note-:0222-61)
: 73  The Soviet stance regarding the CCP and the Chinese Nationalists oscillated during this period, and in November 1945 the Soviet Union requested that the CCP withdraw from major cities in Manchuria.[\[53\]](#cite_note-:0222-61)
: 73 

The [Soviet occupation of Manchuria](/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_Manchuria "Soviet occupation of Manchuria")
, along with the northern portions of the Korean Peninsula, allowed for parts of those regions to be transferred by the Soviet Union into the control of local communists after the Soviet withdrawal in 1946[\[54\]](#cite_note-62)
 in spite of [a 1945 agreement](/wiki/Sino-Soviet_Treaty_of_Friendship_and_Alliance "Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance")
 signed between the Soviets and the [Kuomintang](/wiki/Kuomintang "Kuomintang")
.[\[55\]](#cite_note-63)
 The control of these regions by communist governments backed by Soviet authorities would be a factor in the rise of the CCP and shape the political conflict of the [Korean War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War")
.\[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")\
_\]

Several thousand Japanese who were sent as colonizers to Manchukuo and Inner Mongolia were left behind in China. [Japanese nationality laws](/w/index.php?title=Japanese_nationality_laws&action=edit&redlink=1 "Japanese nationality laws (page does not exist)")
 allowed only children fathered by Japanese fathers to become Japanese citizens.\[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")\
_\]

In late 1949, numerous members of the former Kwantung Army who had been captured in the Soviet invasion of Manchuria were convicted in connection with the activities of [Unit 731](/wiki/Unit_731 "Unit 731")
, and related units for their connections with crimes against humanity and the use of [chemical](/wiki/Chemical_weapons "Chemical weapons")
 and [biological weapons](/wiki/Biological_weapons "Biological weapons")
.[\[58\]](#cite_note-66)

War crimes
----------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: War crimes")\
\]

Further information: [Gegenmiao massacre](/wiki/Gegenmiao_massacre "Gegenmiao massacre")
 and [Soviet war crimes](/wiki/Soviet_war_crimes "Soviet war crimes")

Main article: [Rape during the occupation of Manchuria](/wiki/Rape_during_the_occupation_of_Manchuria "Rape during the occupation of Manchuria")

During the invasion of Manchuria, Soviet soldiers killed and raped Japanese civilians.[\[59\]](#cite_note-til-67)
 The most famous example was the [Gegenmiao massacre](/wiki/Gegenmiao_massacre "Gegenmiao massacre")
, Soviet soldiers from an armoured unit massacred over one thousand Japanese women and children.[\[60\]](#cite_note-Ealey-68)
 Property of the Japanese were also looted by the Soviet troops.[\[59\]](#cite_note-til-67)
 Soviet forces responsible for the massacre had carried out the same crimes against civilians in [East Prussia](/wiki/East_Prussia "East Prussia")
.[\[60\]](#cite_note-Ealey-68)

According to Soviet historian Vyacheslav Zimonin, many Japanese settlers committed mass suicide as the Red Army approached. reports indicate that the Soviet troops that occupied Manchuria (about 700,000) also looted and terrorized the local people of Mukden and were not discouraged by Soviet authorities from "three days of rape and pillage." In Harbin, Soviet forces ignored protests from [Chinese Communist Party](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_China "Communist Party of China")
 leaders on the mass rape and looting.[\[62\]](#cite_note-FCJones-70)
[\[63\]](#cite_note-CSM-71)
[\[64\]](#cite_note-72)
[\[65\]](#cite_note-73)
[\[66\]](#cite_note-74)
[\[67\]](#cite_note-75)
 There were several incidents in which Chinese police forces in Manchuria arrested or even killed Soviet troops for committing various crimes, leading to some conflicts between the Soviet and Chinese authorities in Manchuria.[\[68\]](#cite_note-76)

During the [Soviet occupation of North Korea](/wiki/Soviet_Civil_Administration "Soviet Civil Administration")
, it was reported that Soviet soldiers committed rape against both [Japanese](/wiki/Japanese_people "Japanese people")
 and [Korean](/wiki/Koreans "Koreans")
 women alike in the northern half of the Korean peninsula.[\[69\]](#cite_note-77)
[\[70\]](#cite_note-78)
 Soviet soldiers also looted the property of both Japanese and Koreans living in northern Korea.[\[71\]](#cite_note-:0-79)
 The Soviets laid claim to Japanese enterprises in Manchuria and northern Korea and took valuable materials and industrial equipment.[\[62\]](#cite_note-FCJones-70)
[\[71\]](#cite_note-:0-79)

Konstantin Asmolov of the Center for Korean Research of the [Russian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Russian_Academy_of_Sciences "Russian Academy of Sciences")
 dismisses Western accounts of Soviet violence against civilians in the Far East as exaggeration and rumor and contends that accusations of mass crimes by the Red Army inappropriately extrapolate isolated incidents regarding the nearly 2,000,000 Soviet troops in the Far East into mass crimes."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Wikipedia article discusses the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in August 1945, a key event in the Soviet–Japanese War. The invasion, also known as Operation August Storm, involved the Soviet Union invading the Japanese puppet state of Manchukuo. The 2nd Far Eastern Front was deployed in a supporting attack role. The article mentions the involvement of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in Soviet-occupied Manchuria and the transfer of control of regions to local communists after the Soviet withdrawal. The article also mentions war crimes committed by Soviet soldiers, including killings and rapes of Japanese civilians. <image:k>

In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:

* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

Also known as: Dongbei, Guandong, Guanwei, Northeast, Northeast Provinces, Tung-pei

News •
------

[Japan and China commemorate World War II anniversary on different dates](/news/361449/83b0bddf72a6de4700375cb7586f921d)
 • Aug. 14, 2025, 4:49 AM ET (AP)

Show less

[![Russo-Japanese War](https://cdn.britannica.com/79/71079-050-69A89620/warship-action-Japanese-coast-province-Liaoning-Liaodong.jpg?w=300)](https://cdn.britannica.com/79/71079-050-69A89620/warship-action-Japanese-coast-province-Liaoning-Liaodong.jpg)

[Russo-Japanese War](https://cdn.britannica.com/79/71079-050-69A89620/warship-action-Japanese-coast-province-Liaoning-Liaodong.jpg)
Japanese warship in action (1904) off the coast of the Liaodong Peninsula, Liaoning province, China, during the Russo-Japanese War.(more)

In the closing decades of the 19th century, foreign powers, particularly [Russia](https://www.britannica.com/place/Russia)
 and [Japan](https://www.britannica.com/place/Japan)
, began to eye Manchuria as a fruitful field for imperialist expansion. The conflict between Russia and Japan for the control of Manchuria first raged over the possession of the [Liaodong Peninsula](https://www.britannica.com/place/Liaodong-Peninsula)
. As the prize of its victory in the [Sino-Japanese War](https://www.britannica.com/event/First-Sino-Japanese-War-1894-1895)
 of 1894–95, Japan demanded from [China](https://www.britannica.com/place/China)
 the cession of the Liaodong Peninsula. But Russia, backed by France and Germany, compelled Japan to abandon this claim. By means of intrigue and intimidation, Russia then (in 1898) acquired from China a 25-year lease of the Liaodong Peninsula and the right to build a connecting railway from the ports of Dairen (Dalian) and Port Arthur (Lüshun) to the [Chinese Eastern Railway](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Chinese-Eastern-Railway)
. The clash of Russian and Japanese interests in Manchuria and Korea led to the outbreak of the [Russo-Japanese War](https://www.britannica.com/event/Russo-Japanese-War)
 of 1904–05. After its defeat, Russia ceded to Japan all its interests in southern Manchuria.

After the [Chinese Revolution](https://www.britannica.com/event/Chinese-Revolution-1911-1912)
 of 1911, Manchuria came under the [nominal](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/nominal)
 control of the local [warlord](https://www.britannica.com/topic/warlord-Chinese-history)
 [Zhang Zuolin](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Zhang-Zuolin)
, who was forced to grant the [Japanese](https://www.britannica.com/topic/history-of-Japan)
 vast [concessions](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/concessions)
 in the region in return for their tacit military support. The [notorious](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/notorious)
 [Twenty-one Demands](https://www.britannica.com/event/Twenty-one-Demands)
 that Japan presented to China in 1915 compelled the Chinese to extend Japan’s lease on the territory of Kwantung (Pinyin: Guandong; at the tip of the Liaodong Peninsula) for 99 years and to grant the Japanese far-reaching civil and commercial privileges in Manchuria."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result from Britannica discusses the history of Manchuria, including the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905) where Japan and Russia fought for control of the region. <image:1>, <image:2>, <image:3>. The article mentions that in the late 19th century, Russia and Japan eyed Manchuria for imperialist expansion. The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica wrote the article, and it was last updated on August 14, 2025.

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

## Actions
```
web_search("China Japan invasion Russia")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://warfarehistorynetwork.com/article/the-soviet-invasion-of-manchuria-led-to-japans-greatest-defeat/): 
Content: "This brought on the first armed clash between Russian and Japanese forces in late July 1938.

!Japan's greatest defeat in World War i <image:7767>

In an attempt to halt the Soviet invasion of Manchuria, Japanese infantrymen board a train bound for the front. The Japanese, by now fully involved in the so-called “China Incident,” ignored the threat.

The Japanese had a low opinion of Russian military prowess, anyway. <image:7765>

The Soviet Invasion of Manchuria led to Japan’s Greatest Defeat
===============================================================

_**Operation August Storm, the massive 1945 Soviet invasion of Manchuria, was Japan’s death blow, and brought an end to World War II.**_

_This article appears in: [Spring 2018](/issue/wwii-quarterly-spring-2018-issue)
_

**By Nathan N. Japanese militarists saw the civil war in China between Chiang Kai-shek’s Nationalists and Mao Tse-tung’s Communists as an opportunity for a place at the imperialist table and a slice of the Chinese pie, and thus decided to invade China, Manchuria, and Korea.

The Imperial Japanese Army was particularly interested in showcasing its skills. As the situation in China deteriorated, the Japanese Army used a series of staged provocations to eventually invade and seize Manchuria. This move, in the spring of 1931, set the stage for the Sino-Japanese War, which would last until Japan’s defeat and surrender in August 1945.

Although a giant in terms of land mass and population, China was viewed by most Japanese leaders in the 1930s and 1940s as a weak and largely defenseless area ripe for colonization and exploitation. Premier Joseph Stalin became increasingly concerned that the Japanese were getting much too close to his own far eastern borders, and the already suspicious Russian leader began to fear their ultimate goals. Most would not return home alive.

Known as the Changkufeng Incident by the Japanese and the Battle of Lake Khasan by the Russians, it would set the stage for all future conflicts between the two nations.

Essentially, a strong Russian force of about 20 infantry divisions massed on the border of Japan’s puppet state, Manchukuo—formerly Manchuria—to prevent any Japanese incursions. The Russian defeat in the Russo-Japanese War in 1905, and the more recent Stalinist purges of his own military hierarchy, simply reinforced an already established prejudice.

When in 1938 there arose a dispute over the exact border between Manchuria, Korea, and the Soviet Union, a high-ranking Soviet defector brought much intelligence to the Japanese Kwantung Army. This defection prompted a local Soviet commander to occupy part of the disputed border line.

Even as diplomatic messages were being exchanged, the ever aggressive Kwantung Army began preparations to eject the Russian “trespassers,” and a Japanese infantry division was rushed to the area."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The article from Warfare History Network discusses the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945, which led to Japan's defeat. <image:7767>. It also mentions the Japanese invasion of Manchuria in 1931 and the conflicts between Japan and the Soviet Union in 1938. <image:7765>. The article was published in Spring 2018.

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

## Actions
```
web_search("China Japan invasion Russia")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria): 
Content: The Wikipedia article discusses the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in August 1945, a key event in the Soviet–Japanese War. The invasion, also known as Operation August Storm, involved the Soviet Union invading the Japanese puppet state of Manchukuo. The 2nd Far Eastern Front was deployed in a supporting attack role. The article mentions the involvement of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in Soviet-occupied Manchuria and the transfer of control of regions to local communists after the Soviet withdrawal. The article also mentions war crimes committed by Soviet soldiers, including killings and rapes of Japanese civilians. <image:k>


From [Source](https://www.britannica.com/place/Manchuria/Manchuria-since-c-1900): 
Content: The search result from Britannica discusses the history of Manchuria, including the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905) where Japan and Russia fought for control of the region. <image:1>, <image:2>, <image:3>. The article mentions that in the late 19th century, Russia and Japan eyed Manchuria for imperialist expansion. The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica wrote the article, and it was last updated on August 14, 2025.


From [Source](https://warfarehistorynetwork.com/article/the-soviet-invasion-of-manchuria-led-to-japans-greatest-defeat/): 
Content: The article from Warfare History Network discusses the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945, which led to Japan's defeat. <image:7767>. It also mentions the Japanese invasion of Manchuria in 1931 and the conflicts between Japan and the Soviet Union in 1938. <image:7765>. The article was published in Spring 2018.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results discuss historical conflicts involving Japan, Russia, and China. One article from Wikipedia ([Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria)) details the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945, including the involvement of the Chinese Communist Party and war crimes committed by Soviet soldiers. Another article from Britannica ([Source](https://www.britannica.com/place/Manchuria/Manchuria-since-c-1900)) discusses the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905) and the imperialist expansion in Manchuria.

A Warfare History Network article ([Source](https://warfarehistorynetwork.com/article/the-soviet-invasion-of-manchuria-led-to-japans-greatest-defeat/)) focuses on the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945, which led to Japan's defeat, and mentions the Japanese invasion of Manchuria in 1931 and conflicts between Japan and the Soviet Union in 1938. <image:k>, <image:1>, <image:7767>, <image:7765>

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

## Actions
```
web_search("China Japan invasion Russia")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results discuss historical conflicts involving Japan, Russia, and China. One article from Wikipedia ([Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria)) details the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945, including the involvement of the Chinese Communist Party and war crimes committed by Soviet soldiers. Another article from Britannica ([Source](https://www.britannica.com/place/Manchuria/Manchuria-since-c-1900)) discusses the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905) and the imperialist expansion in Manchuria.

A Warfare History Network article ([Source](https://warfarehistorynetwork.com/article/the-soviet-invasion-of-manchuria-led-to-japans-greatest-defeat/)) focuses on the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945, which led to Japan's defeat, and mentions the Japanese invasion of Manchuria in 1931 and conflicts between Japan and the Soviet Union in 1938. <image:k>, <image:1>, <image:7767>, <image:7765>


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence details historical conflicts between Japan, China, and Russia, including the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945 ([Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria)) and the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905) ([Source](https://www.britannica.com/place/Manchuria/Manchuria-since-c-1900)). The Warfare History Network article ([Source](https://warfarehistorynetwork.com/article/the-soviet-invasion-of-manchuria-led-to-japans-greatest-defeat/)) also mentions the Japanese invasion of Manchuria in 1931 and conflicts between Japan and the Soviet Union in 1938.

The provided search results focus on past conflicts and do not provide any information about current plans for China and Japan to invade Russia.

The claim cannot be verified with the provided evidence. The evidence only covers historical conflicts and does not mention any current plans for invasion.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

## Actions
```
web_search("China Japan invasion Russia")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results discuss historical conflicts involving Japan, Russia, and China. One article from Wikipedia ([Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria)) details the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945, including the involvement of the Chinese Communist Party and war crimes committed by Soviet soldiers. Another article from Britannica ([Source](https://www.britannica.com/place/Manchuria/Manchuria-since-c-1900)) discusses the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905) and the imperialist expansion in Manchuria.

A Warfare History Network article ([Source](https://warfarehistorynetwork.com/article/the-soviet-invasion-of-manchuria-led-to-japans-greatest-defeat/)) focuses on the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945, which led to Japan's defeat, and mentions the Japanese invasion of Manchuria in 1931 and conflicts between Japan and the Soviet Union in 1938. <image:k>, <image:1>, <image:7767>, <image:7765>


## Elaboration
The evidence details historical conflicts between Japan, China, and Russia, including the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945 ([Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria)) and the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905) ([Source](https://www.britannica.com/place/Manchuria/Manchuria-since-c-1900)). The Warfare History Network article ([Source](https://warfarehistorynetwork.com/article/the-soviet-invasion-of-manchuria-led-to-japans-greatest-defeat/)) also mentions the Japanese invasion of Manchuria in 1931 and conflicts between Japan and the Soviet Union in 1938.

The provided search results focus on past conflicts and do not provide any information about current plans for China and Japan to invade Russia.

The claim cannot be verified with the provided evidence. The evidence only covers historical conflicts and does not mention any current plans for invasion.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results primarily discuss historical conflicts involving Japan, China, and Russia, such as the Soviet invasion of Manchuria and the Russo-Japanese War. However, the search results do not provide any information about current plans for China and Japan to invade Russia.

`not enough information`

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Example: web_search()

Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](http://www.en.kremlin.ru/events/president/news/77864): 
Content: "Through those severe trials, the finest traditions of friendship and mutual assistance were forged and strengthened – traditions that today form a solid foundation for Russian-Chinese relations.

I would remind you that even before the full-scale outbreak of the Second World War, in the 1930s, when Japan treacherously launched a war of aggression against China, the Soviet Union extended a helping hand to the Chinese people. How should China and Russia jointly defend their shared historical memory at a time when some forces on the international stage are attempting to distort historical truth?

**V.Putin:** As I have already noted, this year, together with our Chinese friends, we commemorate the 80th anniversary of Victory in the Great Patriotic War and the capitulation of militarist Japan, which marked the end of the Second World War.

The peoples of the Soviet Union and China bore the brunt of the fighting and suffered the heaviest losses. In 1945, the Manchurian Strategic Offensive Operation played a decisive role in liberating northeast China, dramatically altering the situation in the Far East and making the capitulation of militarist Japan inevitable.

In Russia, we will never forget that China's heroic resistance was one of the crucial factors that prevented Japan from stabbing the Soviet Union in the back during the darkest months of 1941–1942. Japanese militarism is being revived under the pretext of imaginary Russian or Chinese threats, while in Europe, including Germany, steps are being taken towards the re-militarisation of the continent, with little regard for historical parallels.

Russia and China resolutely condemn any attempts to distort the history of the Second World War, glorify Nazis, militarists and their accomplices, members of death squads and killers, or to defame Soviet liberators. To mark the 80th anniversary of the USSR's Victory in the Great Patriotic War, China's Victory in the War of Resistance against Japanese Aggression, and the founding of the United Nations, we signed a Joint Statement on Further Deepening the China–Russia Comprehensive Strategic Partnership of Coordination for a New Era. What are your plans for further promoting high-quality, mutually beneficial cooperation between China and Russia?

**V.Putin:** Economic relations between Russia and China have reached an unprecedented level. What prospects do you see for further promoting ties between the peoples of China and Russia?

**V.Putin:** Large-scale bilateral cultural and humanitarian initiatives make a significant contribution to fostering friendly relations. The Russia-China Roadmap for Humanitarian Cooperation until 2030, which includes more than 100 major projects, is being consistently implemented.

I would particularly highlight the successful organisation of the Russia and China Years of Culture, held in 2024–2025 and timed to the 75th anniversary of diplomatic relations between our countries. This is undoubtedly a strategic dimension of our relationship, helping to build a broad public base of friendship, good-neighbourliness, and mutual understanding.

**Question**: The Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO), jointly established by China and Russia, serves as an important platform for comprehensive regional cooperation, crucial for ensuring peace, stability, and development across the Eurasian space. In your view, in which areas should member states further strengthen exchanges and cooperation?

**V.Putin:** The establishment of the SCO in 2001 embodied the shared aspiration of Russia, China, and the Central Asian states – Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan – to build trust, friendship, and good-neighbourly relations, and to promote peace and stability in the region.

Over the years, the SCO has developed a solid legal and institutional framework, creating mechanisms that enable effective cooperation in politics, security, trade and investment, as well as cultural and humanitarian exchanges."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Kremlin's website discusses the strong relationship between Russia and China, highlighting their historical friendship and cooperation, especially during WWII. It mentions the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) as a platform for regional cooperation. The article also mentions the 80th anniversary of Victory in the Great Patriotic War and the capitulation of militarist Japan.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

## Actions
```
web_search("China Japan invasion Russia")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results discuss historical conflicts involving Japan, Russia, and China. One article from Wikipedia ([Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria)) details the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945, including the involvement of the Chinese Communist Party and war crimes committed by Soviet soldiers. Another article from Britannica ([Source](https://www.britannica.com/place/Manchuria/Manchuria-since-c-1900)) discusses the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905) and the imperialist expansion in Manchuria.

A Warfare History Network article ([Source](https://warfarehistorynetwork.com/article/the-soviet-invasion-of-manchuria-led-to-japans-greatest-defeat/)) focuses on the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945, which led to Japan's defeat, and mentions the Japanese invasion of Manchuria in 1931 and conflicts between Japan and the Soviet Union in 1938. <image:k>, <image:1>, <image:7767>, <image:7765>


## Elaboration
The evidence details historical conflicts between Japan, China, and Russia, including the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in 1945 ([Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria)) and the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905) ([Source](https://www.britannica.com/place/Manchuria/Manchuria-since-c-1900)). The Warfare History Network article ([Source](https://warfarehistorynetwork.com/article/the-soviet-invasion-of-manchuria-led-to-japans-greatest-defeat/)) also mentions the Japanese invasion of Manchuria in 1931 and conflicts between Japan and the Soviet Union in 1938.

The provided search results focus on past conflicts and do not provide any information about current plans for China and Japan to invade Russia.

The claim cannot be verified with the provided evidence. The evidence only covers historical conflicts and does not mention any current plans for invasion.


## Actions
```
web_search("China Japan relations Russia current")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2025/05/2273370ce1bc-china-russia-leaders-statement-avoided-wording-that-could-irk-japan.html?phrase=Germany&words=): 
Content: "China, Russia leaders' statement avoided wording that could irk Japan
=====================================================================

![KYODO NEWS](/mwimgs/7/2/-/img_727acdf405521b5840c6a46ca2e266d649734.png)[KYODO NEWS](/list/partners/kyodo_news)
 \- May 25, 2025 - 22:24 [All](/list/news)
,[World](/list/news/world)

BEIJING - A joint statement signed by Chinese President Xi Jinping and his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin earlier this month avoided wording that could irk Japan, with Beijing asking to remove such reference so as not to damage ties with the neighboring country, diplomatic sources said Sunday.

The deletion apparently indicates the Chinese leadership's attempt to stabilize its relations with Japan, a U.S. (Kyodo) ==Kyodo

The sources said the draft joint statement originally referred to the two countries' commitment to "maintaining the security of Northeast Asia," which could suggest increased joint military activities by them in the vicinity of Japan.

Japan has repeatedly expressed concerns over joint military exercises between the two countries, including concerted bomber flights and warship navigation, near its territory.

The draft joint statement on deepening China-Russia strategic partnership also says Moscow welcomes investment by Chinese companies in a special economic zone on a group of Russian-held islands claimed by Japan, and that Beijing will cautiously study the possibility, according to the sources.

This sentence regarding the disputed islands, which are called the Northern Territories by Japan and the Southern Kurils by Russia, was eventually deleted, they said. The Chinese leader also watched a military parade in Moscow's Red Square.

Russia and China have been strengthening their ties in recent years, with Beijing opposing Western sanctions on Moscow over its full-scale invasion of Ukraine that started in February 2022.

Xi and Putin pledged to resolutely respond to Washington's "dual containment" policy toward them, according to the joint statement.

The released document urged Japan to "draw lessons from the atrocious crimes it committed" and be "cautious in its words and deeds" on historical issues, and distance itself from militarism.

Putin told Xi that he would be "glad" to visit China to attend a ceremony in September to mark the 80th anniversary of what Beijing calls its victory in the 1937-1945 War of Resistance against Japanese Aggression.

Masayuki Masuda, head of the China division at the Tokyo-based National Institute for Defense Studies, said the reference to deeper Beijing-Moscow military collaboration in Northeast Asia "could have triggered a backlash from Japan, the United States and South Korea."

China probably did not want the document to paint a picture of "a Japan-U.S.-South Korea alliance versus the China-Russia-North Korea camp," he said.

Russia and North Korea have also been expanding bilateral military cooperation under a partnership treaty signed by Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in June last year.

North Korea is believed to have received technical assistance from Russia for its military development in exchange for sending troops to aid Russia in its war against Ukraine.

* * *

[**New U.S. communicating with North Korea**](/news/2025/04/5a3a2f1a8c0d-update2-trump-says-us-communicating-with-north-korea.html "Kyodo News Plus")

Combined photo shows Russian President Vladimir Putin (R) (Getty/Kyodo) and his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping. The territorial row has long been a source of friction between Tokyo and Moscow, preventing them from signing a peace treaty after World War II.

Xi visited Moscow earlier this month for his summit with Putin and to attend a ceremony commemorating the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II in Europe, which Russia observes as Victory Day."
